comment.author: 79549245@N06
comment._content:
However, the statue dedicated to William Smith O’Brien (1803-1864) a leader 
of the doomed rebellion of 1848, was the first monument erected in Dublin to 
commemorate an individual who had stood for armed resistance to British rule. 
O’Brien was also a descendant of the Protestant nobility who traced his 
lineage back to Brian Boru. 
The date chosen for the unveiling of his monument was 26 December 1870

So after 1871....

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: I just worked it out that William Smith O'Brien was my great-great-great-great-uncle (I think).  My maternal great-grandmother (an O'Brien) was his great-niece.  Along with thousands of others scattered around the world.   I only began to find out about him (and other Irish history) through these wonderful [http://www.flickr.com/photos/47290943@N03] photos.  Thanks again, Carol.

comment.author: 47290943@N03

comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 30369211@N00
comment._content: Under the photo Penny Farthing, I dug up the following on the Kingsbridge-Harcourt street horse tram: The line would open on the 3rd June 1872, with horse trams operating on the following route: King’s Bridge, Victoria Quay, Usher’s Island, Usher’s Quay, Merchant’s Quay, Wood Quay, Essex Quay, Wellington Quay, Aston Quay, D’olier Street, Pearse Street (then Great Brunswick Street), Westland Row, Merrion Street Lower, Merrion Square West, Merrion Street Upper, (Ely Place, Hume Street returning Merrion Row), St. Stephen’s Green East, Earlsfort Terrace (terminating at the Exhibition Palace now the National Concert Hall). The tracks turning from Aston's Quay to D'Olier street passed within inches of the bollards, and would certainly be visible. So this is 1871.

comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/nlireland] I suppose early 1872 is possible, but if the tram route was opened on 3rd June, it must have taken some time to lay the tracks. This wikipedia article opens: Dublin tramways was a system of trams in Dublin, Ireland which commenced line-laying in 1871, and began service in 1872

comment.author: 91549360@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/gnmcauley] But the bridge was widened between 1877-1880 and up "till then there was only a single pair of tracks going over it. There wouldn't have been the required radius or need for a line to go inside the statue.......... therefore photograph from 1880ish

comment.author: 30369211@N00
comment._content: These tracks are not going over the bridge, they are going the other side of the statue and along the quays.

comment.author: 30369211@N00
comment._content: There is a photo on page 9 of this .pdf of Carlisle bridge before it was widened, and the statue and horse-tram tracks going past it on both sides are clearly visible.

comment._content:
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/91549360@N03] The picture you link has the O'Brien statue, so post 1870, but it has lots of horse trams, so it's post 1872. Carlisle bridge unwidened means it is pre 1879.

The 1872 latest for this picture is because there are no horse tram tracks...

All that considered I am guessing May 1871.

Such a restrained urban fabric compared to the mishmash that is there now.

comment._content: Manchester United to pay Dublin rent until 2015 - from Irish times today (19/06/13) reference the Lafayette building, which is the building that replaced the main building in the photo. It is for sale for € 3.5m. www.irishtimes.com/business/sectors/commercial-property/m...

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: Bothered by the bollards - they seem to be in a poor state of paint for a relatively recent unveiling. Or perhaps they were much earlier than the statue, originally protecting a large three-arm gas lamp standard, like the bollards at the other end of O'Connell / Sackville Street. See bollard discussion about half way down the page (including this photo) at www.archiseek.com/forum/viewtopic.php?f=49&t=2087&... . ??

comment.author: 77199267@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/beachcomberaustralia] The base of the statue also looks quite worn compared to the statue itself. It's possible that the base and bollards were in place for some time before the statue was mounted on top. At such a busy junction it wouldn't take long for them to show some wear and tear.

comment.author: 66151649@N02
comment._content: Insurance! That's what I do for a living. Great shot... London & Lancashire Fire and Life. Now part of Aviva, L&L came along around 1867 www.aviva.com/about-us/heritage/companies/london-and-scot... L&L was formally registered on October 12, 1861. The company came to Ireland before the end of 1862. archive.org/details/cu31924030202927

comment.author: 30369211@N00
comment._content: I don't think this is necessarily a demolition/rebuild of the building in that engraving. The 1864 work for the L&L offices could have been more of a facelift: only the very top floor and roof are really new.

comment.author: 77199267@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/91549360@N03] Could very well be - here's a drawing of him from the RDS website www.rds.ie/asharedhistory/gallery_detail.jsp?c=19&&am... He returned to Ireland in 1856 and the date range for portraits in the Duggan Collection is 1840-1860 so he would be in his mid 50s by the time this photo was taken.

comment.author: 7922758@N06
comment._content: As its the relatively plain Wide Streets Commissioners building with some added decoration, the building is probably from circa 1800 underneath the victorian dressage of 1864. With the whole building swept away for the O'Callaghan building of 1894-98.
